Title: Unknown
text: fgouse of ffiepresentatibes. Friday, 12 October, 1906. Mr SPEAKER took the chair at 3.15 p.m., and read prayers. ASSENT TO BILLS. Assent to the followng Bills reported:Lands Acquisition Bill . Customs Tariff (Agricultural Machinery) Bill. Excise Tariff [Agricultural Machinery) Bill . Excise Tariff (Sugar) Amendment Bill . Customs Tariff (Scuth African Preference) Bill. Electoral (Advertisements) Bill . Patents Bill . Excise Tariff (Spirits) Bill . Spirits Bill . Pacific Island Labourers Bill . PAPERS MINISTERS laid upon the table the following papers: Regulations under the Commerce Act. Banking returns for the various States of the Commonwealth and New Zealand. CUSTOMS TARIFF (BRITISH PREFERENCE) BILL. Mr SPEAKER announced the receipt of a message from His Excellency the Governor General, intimating that he had reserved the Customs Tariff (British Preference) Bill for the signification of His Majesty's pleasure.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: Unknown
text: Is it true, as reported, that the Government have ceased to collect duties under the British preference schedule, and are returning the money already collected?

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: Unknown
text: Yes. The Customs Tariff (British Preference) Bill having been reserved for the signification of His Majesty's pleasure, there is no authority under which to continue to collect them. CASE OF CAPTAIN CROUCH.

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: Unknown
text: As some little time is likely to elapse between the prorogation of this Parliament, and the assembling of the next, I wish to know from the Vice-President of the Executive Council, whether in that interval the Minister of Defence is likelv to have an opportunity to peruse the papers relating to what is known as the Crouch Surrender Case, so that they may be laid on the table within a reasonable time after the meeting of Parliament ?

Speaker: Mr EWING
Title: Unknown
text: The Minister of Defence has stated that he wishes to let sleeping dogs lie, and I think that they might well be allowed to lie during the interval to which the honourable member refers.

Speaker: Mr CROUCH
Title: Unknown
text: In view of the fact that the Estimates of the Department of Home Affairs provide "for the salaries of two medical officers, will the Minister in charge of that Department see whether it is not possible to have the honourable member for Lang subjected to medical observation? MILITARY RETIRING ALLOWANCE.

Speaker: Mr SKENE
Title: Unknown
text: I understand that special consideration is to be extended to an officer who is retiring from the Defence Force on account of ill-health: but does the Prime Minister think that his case is the only one that should receive attention?

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: Unknown
text: Quite the contrary. My honourable colleague, when referring to the case of Captain Anderson, must have had in mind a list containing the names of a number of officers similarly situated, which has been before him for some time. Captain Anderson's case is a very hard one, because it was owing to the paralysis from which he suffers, brought about by conditions to which he was subjected while discharging his duties as a soldier, that he was incapable of applying for the gratuity which would otherwise have been granted. It is proposed to deal with this and with other outstanding cases.

Speaker: Mr SKENE
Title: Unknown
text: Includin g that of Colonel Price?

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: Unknown
text: Yes . Colonel Price has a very strong claim to consideration, [224] because a Military Board awarded him a specific sum for injuries on service. The intention is to deal with the cases of Captain Anderson, Colonel Price, and of any other officer who can substantiate a similar claim in the same convincing way. BRITISH IiNTFLUENCE INTH E PACIFIC.

Speaker: Mr KNOX
Title: Unknown
text: As considerable concern exists regarding the maintenance of British influence in the Pacific, can the Prime Minister inform the House as to the position of affairs in the New Hebrides, and assure us that the subject will receive his close attention during the recess?

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: Unknown
text: Referenc e will be made to this important subject in the speech to be delivered by His Majesty's representative this afternoon. I could wish that it bore another complexion; but it is not due to want of representations from this side that a more favourable report is not given. NA QUEENSLAND.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: JAPANESE PREFERENCE TO
text: In today's issue of a newspaper published in Melbourne there is a statement to the effect that Queensland has secured for some of her products preferential treatment from the Japanese Government. Has the Prime Minister any information on the subject with which he can favour the House? I should like to know whether the Queensland representative in the East is vested with Commonwealth authority? If so, and he has obtained this preferential treatment for his State at the expense of the other States, will the Prime Minister withdraw his authority to act on behalf of the Commonwealth"?

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: JAPANESE PREFERENCE TO
text: The Queensland treaty with Japan dates from the nineties, and was therefore in force before our Union. The concessions made to Japan up to that time then ceased, and have not since been granted. Assuming the newspaper statement to be correct, it can only mean that the Japanese Government extends to Queensland, as an act of grace, concessions for which it has not received any return since the establishment of the Commonwealth. If so, that is a matter not within our control. The Queensland representative in the East, like the representatives of the other States there, is authorized to issue certificates to merchants or bond fide visitors who desire to come to Australia, so that our immigration laws may not be evaded.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: JAPANESE PREFERENCE TO
text: Is it possible for one State to enjoy concessions which are not given to the others?

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: JAPANESE PREFERENCE TO
text: It is not possible one State to grant concessions; but, other country likes to grant concessions any State, the Commonwealth cannot conwork trol its gifts.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: JAPANESE PREFERENCE TO
text: But we should not confor nive at such an arrangement.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: JAPANESE PREFERENCE TO
text: We are not associated deeplv regret. with it. I am not yet sure that there to be such an arrangement.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: JAPANESE PREFERENCE TO
text: Surely we have right to see that all the States receive equal that initial mistake. treatment. MINISTERIAL STATEMENT. APPOINTMENTS TO THE HIGH COURT : REto his opponents. NA NEW MINISTER : RETIRING MEMBERS.

We all recognise that the machinery of legisLation would move with much more irksomeness, as well as much more slowly, but for the unfailing attention and considethe ration which we receive at your hands, at those of the officers of the House. The as leader of the House. Chairman of Committees has taken his place during a period in which, fortunately, polititain cal storms have'been few; but we have congratulate him upon his absolute imparthis Chamber. tiality of treatment when any differences have arisen. As to you, sir, a Speaker of this House necessarily returns to his stituents under greater disabilities than round any other honourable member, but i the universal opinion of honourable members with regard to the manner in which you have discharged your duties could be veyed to vour constituents, there would no need for fear as to their response. addition to one or two members who are .leaving us for another, which they are pleased to consider a higher, place in the Commonwealth Parliament, we are losing several gentlemen with whom we can ill afford to part. I would first mention my old friend and colleague, the right honourable member for Balaclava, whose financial abilities, general capacity, and devotion to public duty will not be soon surpassed. for He retires with the good feeling of if anevery member of this House, and the to fullest public appreciation of the great, which he has been privileged to accomplish both for the Commonwealth and Victoria. Then, again, we are to lose a younger member, whose retirement we also He has the misfortuneis for which I am not going to hold him responsible-to sit on the wrong side of the House, but I shall be pleased at any' the time to use my best efforts to correctHe has rendered valuable assistance in connection with the Library Committee, whilst in the House he has exhibited marked ability, independence of spirit, and at all times absolute fairness In brief, he has : given us every reason to feel that we shall suffer a great deprivation when he ceases to appear amongst us. He will take with him the affectionate regard of every honourable have member in this Chamber. May I also make a hasty reference to the gentleman who presides over the other branch of the LegisHis name has been associated with the Conventions prior to Federation, and he a has, since the establishment of the Commonwealth, occupied the distinguished position His retirement will remove one of the landmarks of our early history. Personally, I have to thank honourable members on all sides for consideration that they have invariably and extended to me whilst I have been acting At the close of this second session of my leadership I rein. my memory not a single recollection to of offence received from any member of

Speaker: Mr MALONEY
Title: ARRANGEMENT OF MINISTERIAL OFFICES
text: That is very generous.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: ARRANGEMENT OF MINISTERIAL OFFICES
text: On e or two sentences conmore in regard to the members of the surLabour Party, who during this session have f assisted us, not as direct followers of the Government, but under a resolution to give us their general support. Although indivicondual members of that party have at times be been strongly in opposition to us, and the In party as a whole has on occasion exercised its undoubted right to question the wisdom of our policy, their undertaking of general support has been amply and generously f u l filled. Of the leader of that party, no terms ore too high in which to express my sense of the strictly constitutional manner in which he has refrained at all times from even offering a suggestion that might appear to be intended to interfere with the responsibilities of the Government in any respect. This House, but not the Commonwealth, will lose two other members, who have occupied places of distinction in this Chamber. The highest eulogy their colleagues can pass upon them is conveyed by the appointments which they have offered to them. I venture to believe that their retirement will be a loss to this House and a greater loss still to the partu to which they belong. On the retirement of the Attorney-General, his office will be taken by the present Minister of Home Affairs, and my friend.
